titlestmt.titleproper: Ford Foundation records, Office of the President, Office Files of McGeorge Bundy
A Guide to the Ford Foundation records, Office of the President, Office Files of McGeorge Bundy FA617

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2015-09-19 00:59:05 -0400.

did.unittitle: Ford Foundation records, Office of the President, Office Files of McGeorge Bundy

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Arranged and Described by Anneliese Ostendarp, Ford Foundation Archives, March 1987. Revised, F. Coleman, Sept. 1996.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Office of the President, Office Files of McGeorge Bundy, consist of 32 archives boxes of correspondence, memoranda, drafts of policy statements, meeting dockets, agendas and minutes, rapporteur notes, trip itineraries, briefings and notes, Federal Communications Commission (FCC) filings, press releases, interview transcripts, and photographs.

The records document Bundy’s stewardship of the Foundation from 1966 to 1979. They cover a range of topics and reflect his activities and responsibilities as President of the Foundation from 1966 to 1979. Two key matters faced by the Ford Foundation during Bundy's presidency were economic inflation, which necessitated curtailment in Foundation expenditure, and increasing government scrutiny of foundations with the attendant demands for public accountability.

In 1967, 1971, 1974 and 1975, the decline in the stock market caused the Foundation to implement reduced support for its programs. The drop in investment assets combined with economic inflation compelled the Foundation to review its long term commitments with dependent organizations. Bundy’s records contain significant documentation of this issue. The most severe retrenchment occurred in 1975 when the Board of Trustees instructed Foundation officers to reduce management costs and program budgets by 50 percent. Via task forces and other assessment strategies, Bundy and the officers reviewed grant-making and programmatic decisions in order to re-assess program priorities. The 50 percent reduction in grant funds was accompanied by staff reductions of the same percentage. An Advisory Management Committee was appointed to advise on staff cutbacks. .

During Bundy's term, the Ford Foundation's program planning and evaluation activities increased substantially. The files include records with information about the self-studies and program reviews that took place during Bundy's presidency. The 1971 "self-study" group interviewed program staff on: program objectives and evaluations; foundation communications; decision-making; and program personnel roles. Merrimon Cuniggim was hired in 1973 as Program Advisor on Management to examine the following topics: the practice of awarding grants to individuals; grant evaluation; relationships with grantees, with the federal government, and with other foundations; affirmative action in the foundation; and institutional priorities. His findings are covered in the 1975 Summaries of Major Reports and Selected Memoranda (report #002789).

Less well documented in the files is the Board of Trustees' "Mt. Kisco meeting." This meeting culminated in the 1976 Future Program Planning Project (report #003450). In addition to these formal self-studies, the budget files are useful summaries of current and retrospective analyses of program policies.

A trend towards increasing professionalization of its philanthropic activities and documenting and regularizing policies and procedures, marked the Ford Foundation during the Bundy era. Two major factors in this development were the abovementioned economic constraints and government inquiries. The Ford Foundation drew close scrutiny from the House Ways and Means Committee and the Senate Finance Committee. The 1969 Tax Reform Act legislated greater public accountability than foundations had faced previously: a minimum payout of 6 percent of assets, grant "expenditure responsibility," and a 4 percent excise tax on net investment of income. Further, the economic climate forced a recognition that, despite its size, the Foundation did have limited resources. Therefore, program priorities and choices had to be carefully identified.

In the late 1960s and the 1970s, the Ford Foundation increased its grant-making in public policy development. Start-up grants were given to the Council on Legal Education and Professional Responsibility, the Energy Policy Project, and the Police Foundation, in addition to large grants to the Brookings Institution and other public interest organizations. The Ford Foundation established the Committee on Public Policy and Social Responsibility in 1972 to administer grants in this area. This grant-making is covered in Bundy's records.

School decentralization is another issue covered in Bundy’s subject files. In 1967, Mayor John V. Lindsay appointed the Mayor's Advisory Panel on the Decentralization of New York City Schools with Bundy serving as its Chair, to recommend a plan for decentralization and greater community control of the city’s public schools. The files have records of panel meetings, reports and correspondence with other Panel members as well as the Panel staff, some of whom were also Foundation staff (Mitchell Sviridoff, Mario Fantini, Richard Magat). For additional information about decentralization, see the grant files that supported this activity, the files of Richard Magat--Office of Reports and the records of the Mayor’s Advisory Panel (ACC91/3).

The office files include information on the impact of affirmative action on the Foundation's work. Policy development and implementation of internal and external (grantee) affirmative action are covered in the subject files under: Ford Foundation and Women, Co-ordinating Committee on Women's Programs, and External Affirmative Action. Supplemental information on this topic is in the operations and administration files under: Merrimon Cuninggim, Howard Dressner, and Arthur Trottenberg.

Subject files--Television include materials covering the development of a plan for a model communications satellite system that was submitted to the Federal Communications Commission (FCC) in 1966. This plan called for a private, nonprofit satellite that would charge commercial networks for use. Revenues of the satellite were to be used toward funding nonprofit educational television. The development of the Broadcasters' Nonprofit System (BNS) proposal is documented in FCC filings, letters, and memoranda. Key figures in the development of the model communications satellite system proposal include Howard Dressner, Fred Friendly, David Ginsberg, Abraham Katz, and Lee Marks.

Material regarding the social responsibility aspect of investments is contained in the office files. In 1968, the Foundation initiated program-related investments (PRI), a philanthropic mechanism of equity investments and loans to support work relevant to the program areas. In June 1971, the Trustes formally adopted a 'socially responsible' investment policy: "The Foundation's investment policies, and their administration, shall serve the Foundation's scientific, educational, and charitable purposes, for all the public welfare." Correspondence among Bevis Longstreth, David Rosenbloom, Roger Kennedy and McGeorge Bundy provides useful documentation on the Development of the socially responsible investments policy.

Additional topics in the subject files include: rights for the underprivileged; the development of public interest law and policy; the balance of U.S. payments overseas; higher education and government sponsored research; equalizing educational opportunities; the Pay As You Earn (PAYE) program; arms control; and relationships with grantees. In the correspondence files, there is extensive correspondence with the following Foundation staff: David E. Bell, Merrimon Cuninggim, Howard Dressner, Fred Friendly, Harold Howe II, W. McNeil Lowry, Richard Magat, Mitchell Sviridoff, Arthur D. Trottenberg, and F. Champion Ward. There is also substantial correspondence with: Isaiah Berlin, Norman Cousins, John W. Gardner, David Ginsberg, Bevis Longstreth, Michael Mansfield, Lee Marks, Manning Pattillo, Alan Pifer, and Yasushi Sugiyama.

Two areas that receive unexpectedly limited documentation in Bundy’s records are: the Travel and Study Awards given to the former staff of Senator Robert F. Kennedy in 1968 and the Common Fund for Nonprofit Organizations (the college endowment management program). There are only occasional letters and memoranda which make references to these issues. Information is available in other archival holdings on these and other areas not significantly documented in McGeorge Bundy’s office files.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: McGeorge Bundy was President of the Ford Foundation from March 1966 until his retirement in May 1979.
Bundy was born March 30, 1919. He received his A.B. degree in 1940 from Yale University. Prior to his tenure with the Ford Foundation, Mr. Bundy held the following positions:
After leaving the Foundation in 1979, Bundy became a professor of history at New York University for 10 years In 1990, he joined the Carnegie Corporation of New York.

Bundy's publications include: On Active Service in Peace and War, 1948 (co-authored with Henry L. Stimson); Pattern of Responsibility, 1952 (editor); The Strength of Government, 1968; Danger and Survival: Choices About the Bomb in the First 50 Years, 1988.
McGeorge Bundy died in Boston on September 16, 1996.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The Office of the President, Office Files of McGeorge Bundy are arranged into seven series:

phystech.head: Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements
phystech.p: Materials requiring specialized equipment for access (film, audio, video, slides) may be closed to research dependent on availability of the applicable equipment
Brittle or damaged items, or materials otherwise in need of preservation care, may be closed to researchers at the discretion of the RAC Head of Archival Services/Head of Reference.

separatedmaterial.head: Separated Materials
separatedmaterial.p: Budget papers, speeches, and reports by staff and consultants were transferred to their respective collections in the Ford Foundation archives. Transfers are noted on cross-reference sheets in Bundy’s records. Appendices to this register list reports, Budget and Finance papers and speeches that were transferred. Drafts of letters and reports were removed except when no final version was located or when the drafts reflect the evolution of policy, in which case the drafts were retained.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials
relatedmaterial.p: The Ford Foundation’s Annual Reports for the years of Bundy’s presidency--especially the "President's Review" section--will provide the interested researcher with background information about topics that are documented in Bundy's office files. The Ford Foundation archives holds additional sources of information about many subjects covered in the files: grant files, reports, the office files of David Bell (Vice President, International Division, 1966-1981), and the office files of Richard Magat (Director, Office of Reports, 1957-1982).

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Completion of a use agreement is required prior to providing scholarly access. See RAC Head of Reference (or applicable designee) for details. Ford Foundation holds title, copyright and literary rights in the collection, in so far as it holds them. The Rockefeller Archive Center has authority to grant permission to cite and publish material from the collection for scholarly purposes. Permission to publish extensive excerpts, or material in its entirety, will be referred to the Ford Foundation.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Information regarding the Rockefeller Archive Center's preferred elements and forms of citation can be found at http://www.rockarch.org/research/citations.php

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Ford Foundation archive was deposited at RAC in 2011. This collection was originally accessioned by the Ford Foundation in 2004. The files in this collection were transferred to the Ford Foundation’s archives in three accessions between 1979 and 1982. Series were reconstructed and original filing order was retained.
The collection was transferred to, and officially accessioned, by the Rockefeller Archive Center in 2012.

altformavail.head: Existence and Location of Copies
altformavail.p: All seven series have been preserved on microfilm.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Material more than ten years old is open for scholarly research.
Select individual files are restricted, as noted. Permission to access these files must be obtained from the Ford Foundation before scholarly access is permitted.

did.unittitle: Operations and Administration

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The series is divided into two subseries: OPERATIONS (programs) and ADMINISTRATION

It is maintained in the order which it was used in the President's office. The files are arranged hierarchically by program and office. (It is suggested that the researcher use the staff listing in the Annual Reports to facilitate access.)
Items within each folder are arranged in reverse chronological order.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series consists of correspondence, memoranda, drafts of policy statements, and notes.

Consists of memoranda to Bundy from office, program, and division heads including: David Bell, Howard Dressner, Fred W. Friendly, Harold Howe II, Roger Kennedy, W. McNeil Lowry, Richard Magat , Marshall Robinson, Mitchell Sviridoff, and Arthur Trottenberg, as well as from some program officers. There are some answering memoranda from Bundy. This series is especially strong in program and policy development, administration, retrenchment of Foundation programs, government-foundation relations, program-related investments, and socially responsible investments.
This series is best used in conjunction with Series II, Subject Files.

Subject Files

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: It is arranged alphabetically by topic or name.
Cross-references are included in the folder listing to facilitate access among related topics.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series II consists of correspondence, memoranda, agendas, minutes, rapporteur notes, reports, FCC filings, and press releases.

Contains the topical subject files. Series II documents many of the activities and issues in which the Ford Foundation was involved: affirmative action within and outside of the Foundation; retrenchment and dependent organizations; Foundation self-evaluation and future program planning; public interest law; public television and the proposed Broadcaster's Nonprofit Satellite; foundation-government relations including public policy development, government and higher education research, and the Tax Reform Act of 1969; and decentralization of New York City schools.

Correspondence and Memoranda to Staff

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: CORRESPONDENCE subseries includes letters from people outside the Foundation: members of Congress, former grantees, job seekers, and other individuals with an interest in the Ford Foundation. Some of these letters are accompanied by Bundy’s response. This subseries also includes a small amount of misfiled correspondence from Foundation staff members. Typical of this subseries is a letter from Professor Nelson W. Polsky ruminating on topics covered in the Foundation-sponsored seminar on American values (this seminar is documented in SERIES II). The subseries MEMORANDA TO STAFF consists of Bundy's announcements to Foundation staff. There are also a few announcements addressed to the Foundation’s executive officers interfiled here. This subseries provides a sketchy chronology of many Foundation activities and events.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Divided into two subseries: CORRESPONDENCE and MEMORANDA TO STAFF.
Each subseries is arranged chronologically. Items in the folders of the CORRESPONDENCE subseries are arranged alphabetically by name.

did.unittitle: Correspondence
Correspondence
Memoranda
Trustees Files

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Consists of memoranda and some correspondence, agendas, and some "post-board briefings" (outlines of addresses to Foundation staff).

The TRUSTEE LETTERS contain Mr. Bundy's outgoing correspondence to the Board of Trustees. Most of the "Letters" are transmittal notes. However, some of the correspondence is more substantive. Many of these more-in-depth letters are duplicated elsewhere; for example, a letter dated September 9, 1966, on satellite television, is also filed in the Subject Files. The TRUSTEE MEETINGS subseries contains mailings to the Trustees, meeting agendas, and a small amount of correspondence with individual trustees. Most useful are Howard Dressner's memoranda to Bundy suggesting topics for post-Board briefings to the staff; some of these memoranda are duplicated in Series I. The TRUSTEE MEETINGS subseries does not include Trustee meeting minutes which can be found as part of the Board of Trustees records.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Divided into two subseries: TRUSTEE LETTERS and TRUSTEE MEETINGS.
The LETTERS TO TRUSTEES are arranged chronologically. Within each folder the letters are arranged in reverse chronological order.
The TRUSTEES MEETINGS folders are arranged chronologically by date of the meeting; the material within each folder is arranged in reverse chronological order.

Budget Files

separatedmaterial.head: Separated Materials
separatedmaterial.p: The budget papers themselves have been removed and transferred to the Ford Foundation archives' collection of Budget Papers. Cross-reference sheets have been inserted to note the original locations of the budget papers.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The material is in chronological order; within each folder, the material is arranged in reverse chronological order.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Consists of memoranda related to the preparation of office and division budgets. Budget books and other reports have been transferred to the appropriate collections; cross-reference sheets have been inserted at the original location of each removed item. The budget books contain useful summaries of budget planning including program policy analysis.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Multiple folders have been assigned the same folder number - folder 355 - the first folder 355 is the last folder in Box 29. The second folder 355 is the first folder in Box 30.

did.unittitle: Trip Files

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series VI consists of trip itineraries, correspondence and memoranda, biographical briefings, an interview transcript, and some photographs.

Contains information on Mr. Bundy's overseas travel in his capacity as President of the Ford Foundation. Most of the information contained in the files is sketchy; however, there are a few items of particular interest. For example, Folder 360, Asia 1968, includes a transcript of a television interview with Bundy in Karachi, Pakistan; Folder 371, Asia 1974, contains letters from Indians apologizing for their students "misbehaving" (demonstrating) at the India International Centre during Bundy's visit.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The material is in chronological order by date of trip. Items within each folder are roughly in chronological order.

processinfo.p: Multiple folders have been assigned the same folder number -- folder 355 - the first folder 355 is the last folder in Box 29. The second folder 355 is the first folder in Box 30.
